hypothesis_content.title: Overnight Gap Fill in Low-Liquidity Regimes
hypothesis_content.statement: In NEUTRAL or BEAR regimes, a price gap at the daily open (00:00 UTC) exceeding 0.8% that occurs on below-average volume (volume < 20-day median) will be filled (price trades through the prior day's close) within the first 6 hours of the trading day with >70% probability.
hypothesis_content.rationale: Gaps on low volume in non-trending markets are often caused by illiquidity, not new fundamental information. Market microstructure and arbitrage activity (spot/futures, cross-exchange) tend to pull price back to the last high-liquidity point (prior close). This is less reliable in strong BULL regimes where gaps can be breakaways.
entry_conditions: Daily candle opens (00:00 UTC) with a gap > |0.8%| from prior day's close
First 2 hours of daily volume is below the 20-day median for that same 2-hour period
Overnight funding rates are neutral (absolute value < 0.001%)

exit_conditions.take_profit: Price trades through the prior day's closing price (gap filled)
exit_conditions.stop_loss: Price extends beyond the gap by an additional 0.5% in the direction of the gap
exit_conditions.time_exit: 6 hours after the daily open (18:00 UTC)

hypothesis_content.falsification_criteria: In qualifying conditions, the gap remains unfilled after 6 hours more than 30% of the time, indicating a structural change in gap behavior or increased persistence of low-volume moves.
